articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the South while snowfall blankets Great Lakes region
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida, and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The direct shot of Arctic air affecting the eastern two-thirds of the country migrated east from the Northern Plains. The southeastern U.S. will face a few more colder-than-normal days before warming up later in the week.

articles.title: Climate change expands wildfire danger worldwide, study warns
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: A new study led by CMCC and Coventry University claims that climate change will dramatically affect the planet.      Â   .   i   in the future.  in this way, the climate will change dramatically.  In the future

articles.title: A home is saved in Buxton
articles.author: Outer Banks Voice
articles.summary: A home is saved in Buxton. 15 homes have collapsed on the Cape Hatteras National Seashore since Sept. 30. This photo shows the Buxton oceanfront home and primary residence of Lat Williams after it was moved out of harm's way on Monday, Nov. 10. The structure is scheduled to be moved to its permanent location on Wednesday, November 12.

articles.title: Ethiopia set to host UN's 2027 climate summit, 2026 undecided
articles.author: Nick Perry
articles.summary: Ethiopia will host the UN climate change conference in 2027. The news broke on the second day of COP30, the 30th UN climate conference held in Belem, in the Brazilian Amazon. Australia or Turkey may host the next year's conference, but Ethiopia is most likely to host it.

articles.title: Climate Change and Human Rights talks kick off in Sydney
articles.summary: Representatives from Fiji and the Pacific are currently in Sydney, Australia for a fellowship focused on Climate Change and Pacific. The event is organised by Australia's Diplomacy Training Program (DTP) through Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs. Participants are scheduled to visit three Australian cities advocating on the impacts of Climate Change in Oceania.

articles.title: Philippines ranked 7th most affected country by extreme weather in 2024
articles.author: Mariel Celine Serquiña
articles.summary: The Philippines was the seventh most affected country by extreme weather events in 2024, up four places from a year ago. The report was released as the Philippines is still reeling from the effects of typhoons Fung-wong (Uwan) and Kalmaegi (Tino), which killed a combined total of over 250 people. St. Vincent and the Grenadines was the most impacted in 2024.

articles.title: New report highlights College of the Atlantic's role in Mount Desert Island's economy and community
articles.author: Courtesy
articles.summary: College of the Atlantic has wide-ranging economic, social, and cultural impacts on Bar Harbor, Mount Desert Island, and the greater Hancock County region. COA's operations, people, and programs do more than support the local economy, they help sustain the region's social and environmental fabric.

articles.title: From bush to bin: How Brisbane's wildlife is conquering the concrete jungle
articles.author: Luke Bradnam
articles.summary: Professor Darryl Jones joined Luke Bradnam on 4BC Breakfast to discuss the surprising and thriving ecosystem present in the Brisbane CBD. He uses the example of the adaptable Ibis to illustrate how these animals utilise the city's unique environment to their advantage.

articles.title: ASIO boss sounds alarm on ‘devastating, disruptive' Chinese hacking threat
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess has warned that Australia has 'now reached the threshold for high-impact sabotage' as he sounds the alarm on Chinese hackers. He is concerned about the threat of cyber-hacking from China and other nations.

articles.title: 'The most eerie experience': the day this BoM meteorologist will never forget
articles.author: Katrina Lovell
articles.summary: Mr King grew up on the family farm at Hawkesdale and worked as a severe weather specialist at the Bureau of Meteorology for 36 years. He has seen a lot of changes in the weather and in the way they predict it over that time.

articles.title: Scarcity and spoiled food: The drama left by Hurricane Melissa in Cuba
articles.author: Cibercuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The hurricane Melissa left the eastern part of Cuba without electricity for several days. The Food Monitor Program (FMP) warns that the lack of energy for refrigeration accelerates the spoilage of the few products that families manage to preserve. The organization places the emergency within a network of preexisting vulnerabilities: a fragile economy, collapsed services, and limited community resilience.

articles.title: Report Blames Climate Change For More Iowa Disasters, Rising Insurance Costs
articles.author: Sam Heyn
articles.summary: The 15th annual Iowa Climate Statement was released Monday. It was endorsed by 177 Iowa science faculty at 24 colleges and universities statewide. Bill Gutowski, professor emeritus of meteorology at Iowa State University, says temperatures are rising globally due to an increase in greenhouse gases. Billion-dollar disasters in the region encompassing Iowa have more than doubled over the past 40 years.

articles.title: The Myths We're Told About Climate Change
articles.author: Duane Rolheiser
articles.summary: There is a doomsday view that climate change is a threat to humanity. People will be able to live and thrive in most places on Earth for the foreseeable future. With the right policies and investments, innovation will allow us to drive emissions down much further. The Gates Foundation's top priority is health and development in poor countries. The pool of money available to help the poorest is shrinking as rich countries cut their aid budgets.

articles.title: Southeastern parts of the U.S. experience record-breaking cold snap
articles.summary: Alabama, Florida and Georgia are under a freeze warning. The freeze is caused by an Arctic blast sending cold air over the Great Lakes and it's breaking records in the region. It's coldest on record for this time of the year in the whole region.

articles.title: Think global, solve local Forging Pakistan's climate lifeline
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Zubair Arshad Khattak is concerned about climate change in Pakistan. He proposes two-step plan to build resilience from the ground up based on learning from global successes with a strategic, two-phased approach. The first step is to create Provincial Climate Finance Units (PCFUs) within 12 months. The second is to establish a 'Local Resilience Act' inspired by UK's Climate Change Act.

articles.title: Cold spell brings record low temps to southeastern U.S.
articles.author: HANNAH FINGERHUT
articles.summary: It's the first major cold spell of the season in the southeastern U.S. 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The cold air over the Great Lakes' relatively warmer waters created conditions for significant snowfall in some communities.

articles.title: India improves its Climate Risk Index rank but continues to be among the top ten most-affected countries due to extreme weather events over the past 30 years
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: India has improved both its long-term and year-wise global Climate Risk Index (CRI) rank. India is the 9th and 15th most-affected country globally due to extreme weather events during the 1995-2024 period and in 2024, respectively.

articles.title: The Uninsurable Future of Climate Risk
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom addressed the mounting challenge of insuring properties against climate risks during COP30 climate summit in Brazil. He warned that areas such as Florida, Texas, and Louisiana might struggle to obtain home insurance as extreme weather events like floods, heatwaves, and hurricanes are intensifying.

articles.title: India improves its Climate Risk Index rank but continues to be among the top ten most-affected countries due to extreme weather events over the past 30 years
articles.author: Vishwa Mohan
articles.summary: India has improved both its long-term and year-wise global Climate Risk Index (CRI) rank. It is now the 9th and 15th most-affected country globally due to extreme weather events during the 1995-2024 period and in 2024, respectively, compared to the previous year's assessment. India reported loss of more than 80,000 lives and nearly $170 billion in 430 extreme weather incidents in the past three decades. Dominica, Myanmar, Honduras, St Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada and Chad were the top three most- affected nations in 2024.

articles.title: India improves its rank in climate risk index from 2023
articles.author: Vishwa Mohan
articles.summary: India is the 9th and 15th most-affected country globally due to extreme weather events during the 1995-2024 period and in 2024, respectively. Dominica, Myanmar, Honduras, St Vincent and Grenadines, Grenada and Chad were the top three most affected nations in 2024. India reported loss of more than 80,000 lives and nearly $170 billion in 430 weather-related events in the past three decades.

articles.title: India's Climate Crisis: A 'Continuous Threat' Highlighted by Germanwatch Report
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: India is ranked as the ninth most impacted nation globally by climate disasters over the last three decades. Nearly 430 extreme weather events in India have resulted in over 80,000 deaths and significant economic losses amounting to almost USD 170 billion from 1995 to 2024. India's large population and vulnerability to monsoon variability exacerbate these impacts.

articles.title: Climate Disasters Killed 80,000, Hit 1.3 Billion In India Since 1995: Report
articles.author: Press Trust
articles.summary: India ranks ninth globally among countries most impacted by climate disasters over the past three decades. Climate disasters affected 1.3 billion people and caused economic losses worth almost USD 170 billion from 1995 to 2024. Dominica was the most-affected country, followed by Myanmar, Honduras, Libya, Haiti, Grenada, Philippines, Nicaragua, India and Bahamas.

articles.title: Climate Disasters Killed 80,000, Hit 1.3 Billion In India Since 1995: Report
articles.summary: India ranks ninth globally among countries most impacted by climate disasters over the past three decades. There were nearly 430 extreme weather events killing more than 80,000 people. Climate disasters affected 1.3 billion people and caused economic losses worth almost USD 170 billion from the 1990s.

articles.title: Study Warns: Climate Change in Polar Regions May Intensify Global Health
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In Ambio: A Journal of Environment and Society, Professor Gail Whiteman of the University of Exeter Business School and his team highlight the health risks of climate change. The study synthesizes data from climatology, epidemiology, and environmental science to propose a framework that explains how polar dynamics translate into expanded burdens of disease and health vulnerabilities.

articles.title: Southeastern parts of the U.S. experience record-breaking snap cold spell
articles.summary: Alabama, Florida and Georgia are under a freeze warning. The freeze is caused by an Arctic blast sending cold air over the Great Lakes and it's breaking records in the region. It's coldest on record for this time of the year in the whole region.

articles.title: Pak economic, security, climate challenges
articles.author: Qandeel Raza
articles.summary: Pakistan's economic, security and environmental problems are increasing pressure on the government, institutions and the general public. Recent developments signal short-term economic stability, aided by a staff-level IMF agreement unlocking $1.2 billion. However, structural challenges persist, such as a narrow export base, high import dependence and widespread smuggling undermine local industries. Tensions along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border have intensified. 2025 is projected to be one of the deadliest years for security personnel in over a decade, marked by a rise in violence associated with various militant groups including the TTP, IS-Khorasan and Baloch insurgents. The environmental crisis is among Pakistan's most urgent challenges.

articles.title: OP-ED: Why are women and youth still mentioned separately in climate conversations?
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: Christine Samwaroo and Elishah St. Luce are calling for a truly resilient Caribbean. They believe that women and youth are key stakeholders in climate policy, but they are often left out of the systems meant to protect them from climate change.

articles.title: 10 years since the Paris climate deal: What's changed?
articles.summary: It's been 10 years since the Paris climate deal. What has changed since then? Watch the video to find out. It's duration is 2:28. It is about the Paris Climate Deal and the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, which was signed in Paris.

articles.title: How Climate Change Made Hurricane Melissa Even Stronger
articles.author: The Weather Channel
articles.summary: Melissa was a monster storm. Scientists believe climate change made it even stronger because of the warming world. Watch the video to see how it happened.      Â   yestereffects of climate change are shown in the video.

articles.title: Hunger and food wastage
articles.author: Muhammad Ali Falak
articles.summary: The writer is a Fulbright alumnus. He met Sada Bahar almost 11 years ago. He was serving tea on the outskirts of Bahawalnagar at a small roadside stall. Sada used to work on his farmland, but due to the rising cost of production, losses and lack of storage facilities, they are no longer able to afford their generation-old occupation. The future of food depends on policies that are lasting and adaptable.

articles.title: These Central Florida cities set cold-weather records. Here's the warmup timeline
articles.author: David Nazario
articles.summary: The cold blast we'd been tracking the last several days delivered across our viewing area overnight Tuesday morning. Temperatures went down like a landslide throughout the mid-afternoon/early evening time Monday. Overnight lows set records in several spots around our neighborhood. The high pressure that was yanked south by our polar front jet stream came from the central Canadian provinces. It's now hanging out with all of us southern folk over Mississippi and Alabama.

articles.title: Gaza Fishermen's Union: Fishing Sector Losses Exceed $75 Million
articles.summary: Fishermen's Union in the Gaza Strip estimates total losses at over $75 million due to the destruction of ports, marine infrastructure, and the paralysis of thousands of fishing boats. Fishermen's boats, equipment, storage facilities, and navigation and communication tools were all damaged. Israeli-imposed maritime restrictions limit fishing to narrow coastal areas.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast U.S. while snowfall blankets parts of the Northeast
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. Some daily records were shattered, including a low of 28 degrees at the airport in Jacksonville, Florida on Tuesday morning. That broke the previous record low of 35 degrees set in 1977.

articles.title: Record cold grips Southeast as heavy snow blankets parts of Northeast
articles.summary: The first major cold spell of the season plunged parts of the southeastern US into record-low temperatures. 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The cold air over the Great Lakes' relatively warmer waters created ripe conditions for significant snowfall.

articles.title: Removing CO2 from atmosphere vital to avoid catastrophic tipping points, leading scientist says
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: 10bn tonnes of CO2 must be captured from the air every year to limit global heating to 1.7C, says Johan Rockström, according to the UNFCCC's director general. He adds that this is not enough to prevent global warming.

articles.title: St. Johns County Announces Fort Matanzas Beach Ramp Closure for Renovation Starting November 2025
articles.author: Quin Marlowe
articles.summary: The Fort Matanzas Beach Ramp will be temporarily closed starting November 17, 2025. The county and the National Park Service are working together to repair the damage caused by hurricanes. The project also includes the construction of a new ADA-compliant timber boardwalk and a new asphalt paving.

articles.title: The Australian govt essentially signed a death notice for our regional security
articles.author: Chris Barrie
articles.summary: Instability is on the march and a new insecurity shadows our lives and future relations between nations. Climate change presents a grave and potentially existential threat to society and human wellbeing. In vulnerable countries, climate disruption has contributed to civil wars and government collapse. In our region, climate heating will have profound consequences, especially for food security and the forced displacement of hundreds of millions of people. By 2050, Vietnam's great river deltas could be almost entirely inundated by typhoons and storm surges. Saltwater intrusion will destroy rice production. Vietnam is the world's third-largest rice exporter. In Bangladesh, a one-metre sea-level rise will inundate 20 per cent of the country

articles.title: The Australian govt essentially signed a death notice for our regional security
articles.author: Chris Barrie
articles.summary: Climate change presents a grave threat to society and human wellbeing. The National Climate Risk Assessment shows that Australia is unprepared to face the climate shocks already in motion. New fossil fuel projects will further diminish both security and the stability of the region. Australia has a National Adaptation Plan, but adaptation without serious mitigation is fantasy.

articles.title: Removing CO2 from atmosphere vital to avoid catastrophic tipping points, leading scientist says
articles.author: Jonathan Watts
articles.summary: Even in the best case scenario, the world will heat by 1.7C, according to Johan Rockström of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research. Direct air capture of CO2 would require the construction of the world's second biggest industry and a trillion dollars a year. It would need to be done alongside more drastic emissions cuts. Tim Lenton, a tipping point expert at Exeter University, outlined the range of risks that are already close.

articles.title: Bangladesh 13th in Long-Term Climate Risk Index
articles.author: Staff Correspondent
articles.summary: Bangladesh has been ranked 13th in the Long-Term Climate Risk Index (CRI) 2026. The index documents over 9,700 extreme weather events from 1995 to 2024, which resulted in more than 830,000 deaths and caused over $4.5 trillion in direct damages. Dominica, Myanmar and Honduras are listed as the three most affected countries over the 30-year period.

articles.title: Legal loopholes threaten reef, ex-Treasury boss warns
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef is at risk unless nature law reforms close deforestation loopholes, warns a prominent economist and environmentalist. The law needs to close long-standing deforestation loopholes to protect the reef, he warns. The changes need to be made within the next few years.

articles.title: Are Perth's flies getting worse? Yes – but they're not nearly as bad as they could be
articles.author: Hannah Murphy
articles.summary: Last week's humidity and rain created ideal conditions for fly larvae to hatch, which sparked an increase in the insect around Perth's CBD and broader metropolitan area. November is typically the month WA experiences an influx of flies due to high winds from the north and warm temperatures.

articles.title: Are Perth's flies getting worse? Yes – but they're not nearly as bad as they could be
articles.author: Hannah Murphy
articles.summary: Last week's humidity and rain created ideal conditions for fly larvae to hatch, which sparked an increase in the insect around Perth's CBD and broader metropolitan area. University of Western Australia entomology expert Dr Theo Evans said the influx kept with a broader historical trend.

articles.title: Are Perth's flies getting worse? Yes – but they're not nearly as bad as they could be
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: It's that time of the year again and experts say West Australians must get used to the new buzzy normal as temperatures continue to heat up in the state. It's hot and dry in the West Australia now. It will get hotter in the coming days.

articles.title: A glacier the size of Philadelphia just did something scientists have never seen. They're alarmed.
articles.author: Evan Porter
articles.summary: A glacier the size of Philadelphia just did something scientists have never seen. They are alarmed and they are trying to figure out what it could have caused it.    i.e. what caused the glacier to grow so large and suddenly. i.a.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock southeast U.S. while snowfall blankets parts of northeast
articles.author: HANNAH FINGERHUT
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The direct shot of Arctic air migrated east from the Northern Plains. For much of the Southeast on Tuesday, it was in the 70s and 80s.

articles.title: Take holistic and community-based approach to tackle climate change in NE: Harivansh
articles.author: Bhadra Gogoi
articles.summary: Rajya Sabha deputy chairman Harivansh Narayan Singh called for a holistic and community-based approach to tackle climate change in the Northeast region. He delivered the keynote address at the 22nd Commonwealth Parliamentary Association (CPA) India Region Zone-III conference in Kohima.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast US while snowfall blankets parts of the Northeast
articles.author: HANNAH FINGERHUT
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The direct shot of Arctic air migrated east from the Northern Plains. For much of the Southeast on Tuesday, it was in the 70s and 80s.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast US while snowfall blankets parts of the Northeast
articles.author: Hannah Fingerhut
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through the region. It's the first major cold spell of the season in the southeast.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast US while snowfall blankets parts of the Northeast
articles.summary: 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. The direct shot of Arctic air migrated east from the Northern Plains. For much of the Southeast on Tuesday, it was in the 70s and 80s.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast US while snowfall blankets parts of the Northeast
articles.author: Hannah Fingerhut
articles.summary: The first major cold spell of the season plunged parts of the southeastern U.S. into record-low temperatures Tuesday. 18 million people were under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast US while snowfall blankets parts of the Northeast
articles.author: HANNAH FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The first major cold spell of the season plunged parts of the southeastern U.S. into record-low temperatures. 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes.

articles.title: Record-low temperatures shock the Southeast US while snowfall blankets...
articles.author: Hannah Fingerhut
articles.summary: The first major cold spell of the season plunged parts of the southeastern U.S. into record-low temperatures. 18 million people are under a freeze warning across Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Several inches of snow blanketed areas along the eastern Great Lakes as the blast of cold air moved through. Iguanas began to freeze and fall from trees in Florida.

articles.title: CDB leads Caribbean's push for increased concessional Climate Financing at COP30
articles.summary: Caribbean Development Bank will take the Caribbean's climate agenda to the global stage at the 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) to the UNFCCC in Belém, Brazil. The Bank will lead and participate in a series of evenings.

articles.title: Editorial: Climate Summit — Of lofty talk and unmet goals
articles.author: Telangana Today
articles.summary: Bold statements will not save people from the catastrophic impact of climate change. Only real action — through financial and technological support — can. The fight against climate change cannot be won through mere rhetoric but through genuine cooperation. Global temperatures are surpassing the 1.5 degrees Celsius threshold. Since the Paris Agreement was signed a decade ago, the global CO2 emissions have increased from about 39.6 billion tonnes to about 41.6billion tonnes.

articles.title: Tropics quiet in final weeks of hurricane season
articles.author: Rachel Tucker
articles.summary: The tropics are quiet with just over two weeks left in the Atlantic hurricane season. No tropical cyclone activity is expected in the next seven days. The hurricane season officially ends on November 30th.      Â   .

articles.title: COP30 Bids to Revive 1.5C Climate Goal Amid Island States' Plea
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The COP30 climate summit began in Belem, Brazil. It's focused on achieving the 1.5 degrees Celsius target. The goal is critical for the survival of small island states facing climate threats. Hurricane Melissa's devastation in Jamaica underscored the urgency for action.

articles.title: Richest 0.1 Percent Guilty of the ‘Climate Plunder' Wrecking Planet Earth
articles.author: Jake Johnson
articles.summary: Oxfam report shows that the richest 0.1% of the world's population emit more CO2 than the poorest half of humanity. The report was published less than two weeks before the start of COP30 in Belém, Brazil, where world leaders gather to discuss climate solutions.

articles.title: ‘We are not waiting for permission to survive': A Jamaican perspective on COP30 after Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Janine Mendes-Franco
articles.summary: The United Nations Climate Change Conference, COP30, will be held in Belém, Brazil, from November 10 to 21. The Caribbean is sceptical about the environmental disruption these COP meetings cause. Small island developing states (SIDS) contribute the least to global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Many of the large GHG emitters are not attending the COP30 conference.

articles.title: COP30 and cost of complacency
articles.author: Emran Emon
articles.summary: Bangladesh is one of the most climate-vulnerable countries in the world. The state treats climate change as a sectoral concern rather than as a national priority. Less than one per cent of gross domestic product is spent on adaptation each year, while billions are invested in coal and LNG projects.

articles.title: Great White Shark Bites Huge Chunk Out Of Australian Windsurfer's Board After Dragging Him Underwater (Video)
articles.author: Connor Toole
articles.summary: A great white shark bit a chunk out of a windsurfer's board after dragging him under the water. Australia is second only to the United States in terms of number of shark attacks on an annual basis. There was a decline in the number of such attacks this year.

articles.title: Two elderly people and their son lost everything in Mayarí after Melissa passed through
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa hit eastern Cuba at the end of October. The government promises "guaranteed assistance" for the affected areas, but many people are still living without basic resources. Journalists and activists have documented many cases of people who have not received any help after the hurricane.

articles.title: What to know about Australia's John Allwright Fellowship for research students
articles.summary: John Allwright Fellowship (JAF) is one of Australia's leading agricultural research scholarships. It provides postgraduate opportunities for scientists and economists from partner countries engaged in ACIAR-supported research projects. The 2026 intake will prioritise research on climate change, adaptation, and resilience.

articles.title: Data on weather systems keeping Ireland unusually mild at risk over US funding gap
articles.author: Caroline O'Doherty
articles.summary: Data critical for tracking weather systems affecting Ireland is missing and the body tasked with gathering it is facing a funding crisis. The Global Climate Observing System (GCOS) warned that the loss of the US as a key funder was putting its work in jeopardy. GCOS's work includes improving understanding of Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), the system of ocean currents responsible for keeping Ireland's climate unusually mild for a country positioned so far north.

articles.title: What Bill Gates Overlooks About Climate Change
articles.author: Peter Singer
articles.summary: Bill Gates believes that climate change is a serious problem, but it will not be the end of civilization. The UNFCCC limits global warming to 2°C above pre-industrial levels. Global warming will probably be less than 3°C by 2100. The main reason for this limit is that it is easier to improve people's lives when the climate is stable.

articles.title: News 11 November 2025 Joint Statement on Climate Mobility in Africa at COP30
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Africa's Climate Mobility Agenda is a Call to Action for COP30 in Geneva/Addis Ababa on 11 November 2025. Africa is at a pivotal moment in the global climate agenda and faces a critical challenge. Africa contributes the least to global warming.

articles.title: Climate Goals Threatened by Industrialised Animal Farming, Reveals Key International Study
articles.summary: A new study in Animals argues that reducing livestock production and embracing plant-based food systems is essential for meeting global climate goals. Animal agriculture occupies over 80% of agricultural land, while providing only 18% of calories and 37% of protein consumed worldwide. Without tackling this sector, the chances of limiting global warming to well below 2°C are significantly compromised.

articles.title: Warming seas, policy gaps hurting South Africa's small-scale fishers
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: As negotiators at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil debate global adaptation frameworks, South Africa's coastal fishing communities are already confronting the realities of a warming ocean and restrictive policies. Sean Hogan reports from South Africa on the situation for fishing communities in the coastal areas.

articles.title: COP30: The private sector's make-or-break moment for a 1.5°C future
articles.author: Upworthy
articles.summary: The UN Secretary-General's message could not be clearer: humanity has overshot the 1.5°C limit. The Paris Agreement's temperature goal reflects long-term change over decades, not individual years. What matters now is how fast and how far we change the course of climate change.

articles.title: A Honest Check on the Early National Climate Assessments
articles.author: Dr Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: Congress created the U.S. Global Change Research Program (USGCRP) in 1990. It's the origin of the National Climate Assessment series (NCA1 in 2000, NCA2 in 2009 and NCA5 in 2023). The intent was to summarize observed changes, project future risks, and inform policy. The NCAs have leaned on 'scenarios' and global climate models to infer how the extremes might change.

articles.title: Environmental reforms will fail to protect reef, ex-Treasury boss warns
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Ken Henry will warn that law reforms won't close 'deforestation loopholes' threatening the Great Barrier Reef at a Brisbane lunch on Wednesday. He will talk about the need to protect the environment and the environment in general at the lunch in Brisbane on Wednesday at 12:30pm.

articles.title: Dane Wigington joins Tucker Carlson to discuss geoengineering
articles.summary: The government has finally admitted that chemtrails are real. Dane Wigington explains the government's position on climate engineering.    The Mass Death of Insects and Trees around the Globe is the result of geoengineering. Wildfires are also used as a climate engineering weapon.

articles.title: Maharashtra sweet lime growers face losses and delayed insurance
articles.summary: Sweet lime growers in Maharashtra's Vidarbha region are reporting repeated crop losses due to erratic weather and prolonged delays in insurance settlements. Maharashtra is India's second-largest sweet lime producer after Andhra Pradesh. Heatwaves, droughts, and irregular monsoons continue to affect citrus orchards.

articles.title: Researchers hope AI can help accelerate climate solutions
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is often seen as a climate villain, given the amount of energy required to train and run generative AI models. CNA's Rani Samtani finds out what some researchers are doing out at sea to help tackle climate change.

articles.title: IN AMERICA: ICE fishing
articles.author: Finger Lakes Times
articles.summary: There's a small leak over table 4. Pete thinks the ice built up on the roof and is now melting again.       .   "Pete, there is a leak over Table 4. I'm thinking the ice is melting again."

articles.title: Floods and Filipino hydrological amnesia
articles.author: Segundo Eclar Romero
articles.summary: The Philippines is a water-rich archipelago with 7,641 islands dispersed across 2.2 million square kilometers of maritime space. The country has one of the highest annual rainfall totals in the world, but it suffers from chronic water shortages, urban water crises, seasonal agricultural collapse, and frequent flood disasters. Before colonial rule, water was the organizing principle of Filipino settlement and identity.

articles.title: The Download: surviving extreme temperatures, and the big whale-wind turbine conspiracy
articles.author: Rhiannon Williams
articles.summary: There are currently three active mortality events for whales in the Atlantic. There is no evidence that wind farms are the cause of recent increases in whale deaths. The biggest barrier to progress in the age of AI isn't money but energy. The US needs to learn lessons from the rest of the world on energy abundance.

articles.title: Typhoon Fung Wong wreaks havoc on Philippine agriculture
articles.author: Milena Bogdanova
articles.summary: Typhoon Fung Wong hit the Philippines over the weekend. It caused $2.4 million in damage to the country's agriculture sector. Rice accounted for the largest share of the damage, at more than 116.3 million Philippine pesos (about $1.97 million). Corn, other crops and agricultural land affected by the typhoon were 2,400 hectares. Ministry announced the release of over 380 million Philippine Pesos (approximately 6.45 million USD) to help farmers.

articles.title: Tucker Carlson just told the internet the government's spraying the sky
articles.author: Nazario Rodriguez
articles.summary: Tucker Carlson's new video on X went viral in less than a day. The video features Tucker Carlson and Dane Wigington discussing the 'chemtrails' and geoengineering. The debate shows the erosion of public trust in science and the spread of conspiracy theories on social media.

articles.title: What Labor's green reforms won't fix
articles.summary: Labor's environmental reforms fail to close a '25-year-old loophole' putting the Great Barrier Reef at risk, an economist has warned, as he notes in his new report.    “The 25-year old loophole” is a loophole that has been there for 25 years.

articles.title: Video Installations Triumph at the SAIC Faculty Sabbatical Triennial The 2025 triennial is a testament to the diversity of SAIC disciplines, from video art installations to book-making, and the rich talent of SAIC's faculty.
articles.author: Elisa Shoenberger
articles.summary: Every three years, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago Galleries puts on 'SAIC Faculty Sabbatical Triennial' featuring the work of faculty who returned from sabbatical over the past three academic years. This year's show is a testament to the diversity of SAIC's disciplines, from video-art installations to book-making.

articles.title: 'Deadly Heat': New Science Shows Warming Is 50% Faster Than in 1990s
articles.summary: As COP30 gathers, what's the latest in climate science? Global temperatures are climbing faster than before, with new records logged for 2023 and 2024, and at points in 2025. The world is on track to cross the 1.5 C warming threshold around 2030, after which scientists warn we will likely trigger catastrophic, irreversible impacts.

articles.title: SPACE.com Swallows Lies that Climate Change Is Making Wildfires Worse, It Isn't
articles.author: Climate Realism
articles.summary: SPACE.com ran a story claiming that 2024/2025's wildfires are proof that climate change is making wildfires larger and more severe. Ground based data, where available, and satellite data both show that wildfires have declined in number and acreage lost over the past century.

articles.title: Climate Adaptation Failure Is the Next Debt Crisis for the Global South
articles.author: Jawad Khalid
articles.summary: A new UN Environment Programme report warns that the world is failing to prepare for the climate it has already created. Developing nations will need between US$310 and $365 billion annually by 2035 to cope with intensifying climate impacts. International public finance for adaptation fell to just US$26 billion in 2023.

articles.title: Millions displaced worldwide as climate crises worsen: UN
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: The consequences of climate change have already driven millions of people worldwide to flee their homes, according to the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR) figures released by the U.N. Refugee Agency. UNHCR has released the figures on behalf of the UNFPA.

articles.title: Worker interested in taking polar bear photos at Nunavut site before he was killed
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Christopher Best was working as part of a fuel tank cleaning crew at the North Warning System radar installation on Brevoort Island in Nunavut on August 7, 2024. He was fatally attacked by two polar bears on August 8, 2024, as he was cleaning fuel tanks.

articles.title: Germany seeks to avoid becoming next UN climate host by accident
articles.author: Karl Mathiesen
articles.summary: Turkey and Australia are deadlocked over hosting the U.N. climate conference in 2026. If no resolution is found, Germany is obligated to step in under the rules of the treaty. Germany does not want to host the conference as it would be too time consuming.

articles.title: How climate change increased the risk of earthquakes in East Africa
articles.summary: Climate change is accelerating continental rifting. East African Rift System became more tectonically active after its major lakes shrank due to a drier climate 4,000 to 6,000 years ago. This could have caused more frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

articles.title: Crisis in Chile: Humboldt Penguins Face Extinction
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Humboldt penguins were recently declared endangered by Chile's Environment Ministry. Their numbers have plummeted from 45,000 in the late 1990s to fewer than 20,000 today. They are threatened by commercial fishing competition, habitat loss, pollution, bird flu, and climate change.

articles.title: The Hidden Devastation of Hurricanes
articles.summary: Clayton Dalton talks about the long-term mortality effects of hurricanes in a time of increasingly severe storms amid climate change. He says it's not good to ignore the long term effects of climate change on hurricanes. It's not a good idea to ignore it.

articles.title: Africa: Global Emissions Could Fall 12 Percent By 2035 Under Current Climate Pledges, UN Report
articles.author: Julius Kitone
articles.summary: Global greenhouse gas emissions could drop by about 12% by 2035 compared to 2019 levels if all current national climate pledges are fully implemented. UNFCCC urges governments to "dramatically strengthen their NDCs and accelerate implementation if the world is to keep 1.5°C within reach."

articles.title: BBC has been spreading disinformation about climate change for decades
articles.author: The Exposé
articles.summary: There are persistent climate change claims that rising sea levels will wipe out island nations such as the Maldives. In 2004, the BBC claimed that Maldives were going to be lost, but yet, they are still standing. Please share your story with CNN iReport.

articles.title: The Village that Vanished: Climate change and groundwater extraction threaten homes
articles.author: Transcript
articles.summary: The Village that Vanished is threatened by climate change and groundwater extraction. It's located in a place that has disappeared due to climate change, extraction and other environmental problems. It was once called The Village that Vandalized. Now it's known as The Village That Vanished.

articles.title: Manchester farmer replants field after Melissa's blow
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed Leroy Blake's yam crop in Whitby district less than two weeks after it hit Manchester. He lost 1,500 head of yam and almost half the roof of his home. The overall damage from the storm is estimated at between US$6 billion and US$7 billion.

articles.title: Reboosting agriculture: The key to food security in Jamaica
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed Jamaica's agricultural landscape. The storm has exposed the vulnerability of Jamaica's dependence on imported food imports. Reboosting the agricultural sector is not just an economic strategy, but a fundamental pillar for securing the nation's future. Backyard farming is a powerful, low-cost solution that empowers individual households and promotes community interaction.

articles.title: Fighting the battle over the thermostat, and losing
articles.author: Gareth McGrath
articles.summary: As temperatures begin to fall and the days get shorter and darker, the eternal question between men and women is whether to turn the heat on. A 2017 Dutch study found that four in 10 women covertly turn up the heat behind their partner's back. According to researchers, women prefer a warmer climate than men.

articles.title: What to eat to save the planet
articles.author: Daphne Chouliaraki Milner
articles.summary: It's impossible to solve climate change without fixing the food system. Half of the world's land is used for agriculture and 34% of all greenhouse gas emissions can be attributed directly or indirectly to food. Meat and dairy account for 14.5% of global greenhouse gases. Prawns, lamb, cheese, and certain plant-based products have the biggest carbon footprints.

articles.title: Doctors Slam MP's Bid to Drop Net Zero as Reckless
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The World Health Organisation declares climate change the greatest threat to global health in the 21st century. Doctors for the Environment Australia's executive director Dr Kate Wylie is aghast at attempts to reduce measures towards a safe climate. She urges all parliamentarians to put health before ideology.

articles.title: Bill Gates repeats an Apocalyptic Error
articles.author: Resilience
articles.summary: Bill Gates made news last week by challenging climate advocates to accept the 'hard truth' that temperature rises will not cause climate change, as Bill Gates claims.   Â   in his blog post. He wrote that it is not possible to predict the future of the planet.

articles.title: COP30 highlights urgent need for climate resilience funding
articles.summary: Delegates at COP30 in Brazil emphasized the growing need for developing countries to strengthen resilience against storms, floods, wildfires, and other climate extremes. Developed countries will require $310 billion annually by 2035 for adaptation measures. Development banks have pledged ongoing support, having directed over $26 billion last year. Private financing accounts for just 3% of adaptation funding.

articles.title: Washaway Beach shore restoration moves forward
articles.summary: The Pacific Conservation District and Pacific County Drainage District No. 1 are in preparations to construct a 'long-awaited, long-term' project aimed at restoring and controlling erosion in North Cove. The shoreline had come to be known as 'Washaway Beach' in recent decades after suffering up to 100 feet of land loss per year caused by winter storms, tidal currents and ocean-borne waves. The project aims to rebuild the sandy beach by utilizing dynamic revetment, a nature-based approach that uses materials such as small rocks, anchored wood and native vegetation.

articles.title: Met Office explains why November is unseasonably warm
articles.author: newsdesk@devonlive.com
articles.summary: Bonfire Night was a record-breaker. November's average temperature is 0.7°C above the 1991-2020 average for the month. Chivenor in North Devon recorded a minimum temperature of 14.8°C on Wednesday, November 5. Culdrose in Cornwall had a lowest temperature of 13.8 °C on the previous day. Leeming in North Yorkshire recorded a 13.7 °C temperature on November 5, beating the 2007 record.

articles.title: Oxfam Pilipinas Acts After Super Typhoon Uwan Hits
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Maria Rosario Felizco, Oxfam Pilipinas Executive Director urges the government leaders of the Philippines and other countries to act urgently and seriously to end the climate crisis. Oxfam is working closely with local partners and mobilizing urgent support for families who have lost shelter, livelihoods and access to basic services.

articles.title: Oxfam Pilipinas Aids Typhoon Uwan Hit Communities
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Maria Rosario Felizco, Oxfam Pilipinas Executive Director urges the government leaders of the Philippines and other countries to act urgently and seriously to end the climate crisis. Oxfam is working closely with local partners and mobilizing urgent support for families who have lost shelter, livelihoods and access to basic services.

articles.title: CELAC–EU Summit: PM Phillips calls for renewed multilateralism, climate action
articles.author: Staff Reporter
articles.summary: PM Mark Phillips called for strengthened bi-regional co-operation and renewed multilateralism to tackle some of the world's most pressing challenges, including climate change, food insecurity, and transnational crime. He was speaking at the IV CELAC–EU Summit in Santa Marta, Colombia on Sunday.

articles.title: Unmasking Adaptation: Navigating Financial and Climate Extremes at COP30
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The COP30 summit in Brazil is confronting the challenge of climate adaptation. Developing nations will need up to $310 billion annually by 2035. Development banks have pledged continued support for adaptation initiatives. The U.N. is set to announce a new impact bond to generate $200 million by 2026. Germany and Spain committed $100 million to the Climate Investment Funds.

articles.title: Malinauskas urges federal Labor to hold its nerve over COP bid
articles.author: Phillip Coorey
articles.summary: Peter Malinauskas has urged federal government members to consider hosting next year's COP 31 climate change summit. There are reports of misgivings within federal cabinet and bureaucracy about hosting the 2026 Conference of the Parties summit. The need to reduce emissions is still real, according to the Premier.

articles.title: Can Office Air Conditioning Worsen Your Health This Winter?
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: As winter sets in, office AC systems switch to heating or recirculation mode, workers may face hidden health risks.       .   i   in the office AC system switch to  heating or  recirculating mode, which may pose health risks to workers.

articles.title: Melting glacier exposes the folly of Reform UK's position on climate change
articles.author: 4 minute read
articles.summary: A glacier on the eastern edge of the Antarctic Peninsula has undergone the fastest recorded retreat in modern history, losing eight kilometres of ice in two months. Geraint Davies was the Labour MP for Swansea West from 2010 to 2024. Reform UK leader Nigel Farage is a prominent climate change sceptic and opponent of mainstream climate policies.

articles.title: Unseasonal Rains Devastate Chinese Cropland
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: In October, flooding and geological disasters caused widespread agricultural damage across China, particularly in the north and west. A staggering 364,400 hectares of crops were affected, as rainfall exceeded the historical average by 52%. October's natural disasters inflicted a direct economic loss of 24.9 billion yuan, claiming nine lives, and affecting over seven million residents nationwide.

articles.title: Make robins keep coming back to your garden this winter with one easy trick
articles.author: Katie-Ann Gupwell
articles.summary: Robins are a common sight in UK gardens during the winter months and there's a simple way to attract them to your outdoor space. According to Kingsyard Official, a company that produces bird feeders, adding one basic fruit to your feeder will keep them coming back to your garden this winter.

articles.title: Algal bloom exposes 'limitations' in government monitoring programs, Senate inquiry
articles.author: Thomas Kelsall
articles.summary: The onset of South Australia's devastating algal bloom has highlighted the "limitations of existing research and monitoring programs" along the state's coastline. The committee tabled its 207-page report on Tuesday. The report makes 14 recommendations, including for a new definition for declaring how "climate induced, slow onset and significant ecological events could be incorporated into a broader national framework. It also recommends that the federal government outline clearer responsibilities for all three levels of government.

articles.title: CREWS Unveils 2030 Strategy to Expand Life-Saving Early Warnings Worldwide
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Climate Risk and Early Warning Systems (CREWS) Initiative launched its ambitious new strategy during COP30 Climate Conference in Belém, Brazil. The 2030 Strategy sets a bold target: by the end of this decade, all Least Developed Countries (LDCs) and Small Island Developing States (SIDS) will have access to early warning and climate services capable of safeguarding lives, livelihoods and economies from escalating climate risks.

articles.title: Devil in the beetails: Australian scientists discover new
articles.author: Hong Kong Standard
articles.summary: A new creepy critter has been discovered in Australia. It's the latest creepy crawly to be discovered in the country recently.    in addition to snakes, spiders and sharks, Australia also has a shark and a shark-like creature.  in this case, it's a creature called a kangaroo.

articles.title: Why Africa wants COP30 to recognise its special needs and circumstances
articles.author: FREDRICK OTIENO
articles.summary: Africa's civil society organisations want a dedicated agenda item in climate negotiations to address Africa's special needs and circumstances related to climate change and development. Developed countries and some developing countries have stalled progress on the proposal. Wealthy nations fear recognition of Africa's needs could strengthen specific finance quotas and transfer obligations.

articles.title: Torres Strait Islander Leaders Challenge Australian Government in Landmark Climate Appeals Case
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Two Torres Strait Islander men have filed an appeal in the Federal Court after losing a landmark duty of care climate case against the Commonwealth in July. Justice Michael Wigney dismissed the case, but accepted many of the key facts regarding the serious impacts of climate change on the Torres Strait Islands. The new appeal claims that the judge erred in some of his conclusions. Uncle Paul and Uncle Pabai will continue fighting for their communities.

articles.title: A decade after Paris, how much hotter has our planet become?
articles.summary: In 2015, almost 200 countries signed a landmark agreement to combat climate change. The past 10 years, from 2015 to 2024, have been the warmest 10 years on record. Global warming has accelerated quickly in recent years. It's possible that the 1.5°C threshold will be exceeded for three consecutive years for the first time.

articles.title: Sea level rise 'a very complicated area of science', renowned climate scientist says
articles.author: Senior Reporter
articles.summary: Dr Tamsin Edwards is a climate scientist and author of the IPCC's Sixth Assessment Report. She is in New Zealand this month to give the S.T. Lee Lecture on the topic of uncertainty around sea-level rise in Antarctica. She has 15 years of science communication experience.

articles.title: Australian influencer fined after lighting banned campfire on World Heritage-listed K'gari in Queensland
articles.author: Demi Huang
articles.summary: A woman has been fined $834 for lighting an illegal campfire on K'gari (Fraser Island) last month. She also received a warning for using a drone to film the video above a camping area. The incident serves as a stark reminder that social media creators are not exempt from the rules.

articles.title: Australians Promised Free Solar Electricity
articles.summary: Australia is the sunniest country outside of the Middle East/Africa. It's producing so much solar power that it's going to start giving it away to its citizens during the day. It will be the first time in history that such a thing has happened.

articles.title: This is not anti-trans activism. It is a stand for truth
articles.author: Letters
articles.summary: For Women Scotland is not going away until the Equalities commission's ruling on gender equality is carried out. William Loneskie and Ian McNair are right-wing, but their opinions don't change science. The Yes campaign for Scottish independence ran from 2012 to 2014 and the BBC was frequently criticised for its bias in favour of the preservation of the Union.

articles.title: CREWS Unveils 2030 Plan at COP30 for Global Alerts
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Climate Risk and Early Warning Systems (CREWS) Initiative unveiled its 2030 Strategy: From Delivery to Transformation: Scaling CREWS' Impact to 2030 at COP30 in Belém, Brazil. By 2030, all Least Developed Countries (LDCs) and Small Island Developing States (SIDS) will have the essential early warning and climate services.

articles.title: 'Flying to save the planet? Reader slams climate summit' - Your Letters and the female hands that helped win the war in a Picture from the Past
articles.summary: COP 30 is taking place in Brazil, a country destroying the rain forest and aiming to be the fourth largest producer of fossil fuels. USA and China are not attending. UK with its meagre per cent emissions is there in great force. The worst aspect of the latest BBC crisis is that it allows Donald Trump to cry 'fake news' at others.

articles.title: COP Websites' Carbon Footprint: A Growing Concern
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Website for UN Conference of the Parties (COP) is emitting more carbon than typical internet pages. This reliance on high-computation multimedia content has led to emissions increasing over 13,000% since the first COP in 1995. The importance of refining digital infrastructure is underscored as COP30 in Belem winds down.

articles.title: Climate change? The West vs. others
articles.author: Osa Victor Obayagbona
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa devastated the Caribbean, killing many people and leaving a trail of destruction that could take years to rebuild. Small island nations and developing economies contribute less than 5% of global emissions, yet they bear the brunt of its fallout. Developed nations promised to double their adaptation aid to $40 billion yearly by 2025, but adaptation finance has declined by 15% in the past year.

articles.title: Looking towards Belém
articles.summary: Jamaica was hit by Hurricane Melissa two weeks ago. The damage to private property and public infrastructure is estimated at over US$6 billion. The government is expected to receive US$150 million from its catastrophe bonds and perhaps the same amount from a regional parametric disaster insurance scheme. The World Bank is an obvious early stop for Jamaica. Developed countries pledged US$300 billion in climate financing by 2035 against developing countries' request of US$3 trillion.

articles.title: Building resilience beyond reconstruction
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed a lot of homes in Western Jamaica. The immediate priority is to rebuild now and restore normalcy. There should be emphasis on comprehensive resilience planning rather than a rush for reconstruction. Every dollar spent on reconstruction without resilience considerations is a dollar wasted when the next hurricane arrives.

articles.title: Researchers Probe Permafrost Thaw's Climate Impact
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Permafrost contains the largest terrestrial pool of organic carbon on the planet, exceeding the carbon circulating in Earth's atmosphere. Biogeochemist Suzanne Tank, soil scientist David Olefeldt and permafrost expert Duane Froese have received $1 million from Schmidt Sciences to lead the Canadian arm of a $45-million international partnership to advance our understanding of how the global carbon cycle drives climate change. The fieldwork will focus on the Mackenzie Delta, central Mackenzie Valley, Fort Simpson, Norman Wells and Yellowknife.

articles.title: N-E monsoon likely to remain weak, says Skymet
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: Evolving weak La Ni Ni phase over the Pacific Ocean could suppress north-east monsoon activity, which could affect the monsoon.      Â   i   in the North East Pacific Ocean. It could also affect the East Pacific Monsoon.

articles.title: Animation highlights First Nations leadership in global climate action
articles.author: The National Tribune
articles.summary: The UNFCCC created the Local Communities and Indigenous Peoples Platform (LCIPP) to bring First Nations voices to the table. It helps share Indigenous knowledge and ways to manage and adapt to climate change. Australia is proud to be a member of the LCIPP.

articles.title: 'Terrifying': runway change leads to two near misses
articles.author: Andrew Stafford
articles.summary: "That's why we've been so detailed in the investigation and in our safety recommendations to ensure that this type of thing does not occur, particularly in Australia, again," says Mr. Koonins. "That is why there's been a detailed investigation and safety recommendations."

articles.title: Sabah polls: Green issues might affect voters' picks on Nov 29, says WWF-Malaysia
articles.author: Stephanie Lee
articles.summary: The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) Malaysia conducted a month-long survey across the state of Sabah. It found that 90% of respondents are concerned about environmental issues that will influence their vote in the upcoming state election on November 29. The top environmental concerns were deforestation, waste management, and extreme weather (climate change).

articles.title: AI infrastructure growth threatens 14 million Australian bees a year
articles.author: IT Brief Australia
articles.summary: A University of Sydney study warns AI infrastructure growth could cause the loss of up to 14 million Australian bees annually. It is threatening agriculture and biodiversity, according to the study. The study was based on data from the Australian Biodiversity Programme.

articles.title: Climate change threatens Barunei Island in Kendrapara
articles.author: Post News Network
articles.summary: The centuries-old shrine of Goddess Maa Barunei is under threat from rising seas and climate change. Once a revered but remote pilgrimage site, the shrine has become increasingly inaccessible due to shrinking landmass and severe coastal erosion. Locals fear the island could meet the same fate as Agaranashi, a nearby coastal site submerged in 2023. Bhitarkanika was declared a national park in 1998 and designated a Ramsar Site in 2002.

articles.title: Unseasonal rains damage paddy on over 10,000 hectares in Siraha
articles.summary: Unseasonal rainfall caused by Cyclone Montha damaged paddy crops on more than 10,000 hectares of land across Siraha district. Lahan Municipality suffered the worst damage with crops on 2,232 hectares destroyed, followed by Aurahi and Naraha municipalities. The unseasonal rains and storm caused seeds to rot and plants to collapse.

articles.title: As Bill Gates walks back climate change threats, an apology is in order
articles.author: George
articles.summary: After decades of fear-mongering, Bill Gates admits that climate change will not lead to humanity's demise. The fact that we are due for another ice age could offset some of the worst features of a warming planet. The planet has survived climate fluctuations before and it will survive them again.

articles.title: No rain, no food': Somalia bears the cost of global climate neglect
articles.author: cajnews
articles.summary: Amnesty International report criticizes Somali authorities and the international community for failing to protect thousands displaced by one of the Horn of Africa's worst droughts in decades. The report, 'No Rain, No Food, No Animals: The Human Rights Impact of Drought and Displacement in Somalia,' exposes how neglect, conflict, and global climate inaction have left entire communities destitute. Somalia contributes almost nothing to global carbon emissions but ranks among the seven most climate-vulnerable nations in the world. Somalia allocates less than 5% of its national budget to health, despite pledging 15% under the African Union's Abuja Declaration.

articles.title: Animation Spotlights First Nations in Climate Leadership
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Dept of Climate Change, Energy, Environment & Water shares the second animation in its First Nations series. This story celebrates how First Nations knowledges are guiding global climate action. Indigenous Peoples hold deep connection to land, water, and sky. UNFCCC created the Local Communities and Indigenous Peoples Platform (LCIPP). LCIPP helps share Indigenous knowledge and ways to manage and adapt to climate change.

articles.title: NFA confirms billions in damages to fisheries sector after Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: The National Fisheries Authority confirms that Jamaica's fisheries sector has suffered catastrophic, island-wide damage following the passage of Category Five Hurricane Melissa. Preliminary assessments point to losses in the billions, with fishing communities, aquaculture enterprises and critical infrastructure heavily affected. The worst-affected areas stretch from Manchester westward to St Ann along the north coast, while parishes of St Thomas, Portland and St Mary have also sustained significant damage.

articles.title: Latest UN analysis shows climate pledges cutting emissions by 12%, World News
articles.summary: The yearly amount of planet-warming gases added to the atmosphere will decrease 12% by 2035 from 2019 levels, according to a new analysis published by the UN climate change secretariat. The figure represents progress from the expected 10% reduction announced on Oct 28. It is far short of the 60% emissions drop needed to limit global warming at 1.5 deg C above pre-industrial temperatures.

articles.title: Are Australian women choosing not to have kids because of climate fear? Shocking survey results
articles.author: TOI Lifestyle Desk
articles.summary: 40% of Australian women without children are reluctant to start a family because of concerns about climate change. The survey gathered responses from a nationally representative sample of about 2,000 Australian adults. It found that half the participants described themselves as 'very or extremely concerned' about the climate change and about 40% believed the climate would be 'much hotter' by 2050. The trend has potential demographic and policy implications.

articles.title: Kashmir's glaciers are melting – and water is running out
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Glaciers in Kashmir are shrinking fast. Record heat, cracked rice fields, drying streams and stressed ecosystems are putting communities under pressure. Scientists warn that if this continues, it could mean devastating water shortages for millions. Farmers, researchers and climate activists are raising the alarm over protecting water resources.

articles.title: Beyond adaptation
articles.author: Nasira Habib
articles.summary: Pakistan's agriculture sector is both a victim and a driver of climate change. Agroecology is a scientific and social approach that integrates ecological principles into farming. Pakistan needs an integrated framework where climate, agriculture, biodiversity, and rural development policies work in harmony, and not in separate silos.

articles.title: Researchers reveal troubling update as iconic winter destination nears irreversible change: 'This now seems so unreal'
articles.author: Alyssa Ochs
articles.summary: Norway's climate is changing due to rising global temperatures. The state Meteorologic Institute conducted a study assessing Norway's climate over the past 10 years. The report showed that average temperatures have been consistently rising and that the country will likely lose 32 winter days over the next 75 years. This change impacts Norway's internationally popular winter ski season.

articles.title: Overheated claims about gas barbecues mislead
articles.summary: There is no ban on gas barbecues in Sydney, despite claims on social media. The ban is on gas mains supply, and gas-bottle-fuelled barbeques are unaffected. The new rules apply to the City of Sydney council, representing the CBD and inner suburbs.

articles.title: The Curious Case of the Missing Data
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Ivor Williams is sceptical about the global warming message. He questions the origin of the data used in the IPCC report. He also questions the accuracy of the Met Office data from the 1961-1990 period. The data from HadCRUT5 is even more accurate than the previous data.

articles.title: Teaming up to clean Malaysian air using DAC
articles.summary: Global warming is driven mainly by the accumulation of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide (CO2). CO2 is emitted mainly through the burning of fossil fuels for power, transportation, and industrial processes. Deforestation also reduces Earth's capacity to absorb carbon naturally, which is a major environmental threat.

articles.title: Weather forecast: Wintry blast to bring out the blankets for millions
articles.summary: A wintry blast is coming for Australia's south-eastern states. The cold air mass from the Southern Ocean is spreading across the region. Melbourne is at 5 degrees this morning, while the official temperature is 8 degrees. Hobart is at 7 degrees at midday. Snow is forecast to reach 400 metres above sea level in parts of the state, while small hail and "wintry showers" are also expected.

articles.title: Abigail Hasebroock
articles.author: As Well As News The Cities
articles.summary: Abigail Hasebroock is the Palm Beach County reporter for the South Florida Sun Sentinel. She has covered a range of community issues, as well as news from the cities of Boca Raton, Delray Beach and Boynton Beach. She also has reported about Florida's hot weather, citrus crisis with oranges and the state's ongoing battle with pythons in the Everglades.

articles.title: Influencer blasted for illegal act on island
articles.author: Blake Antrobus
articles.summary: A social media influencer has been fined $834 for lighting a fire on K'gari, a heritage-listed Australian tourist destination. Five years ago, catastrophic bushfires razed most of the island. In October 2020, a bushfire sparked by an illegal campfire near Orange Creek led to more than half of K’gari being burnt.

articles.title: Social media influencer fined $834 for lighting illegal fire on heritage-listed K'gari off Qld coast
articles.author: Blake Antrobus
articles.summary: A social media influencer has been fined $834 for lighting a fire on K'gari, a heritage-listed Australian tourist destination. Five years ago, catastrophic bushfires razed most of the island. In October 2020, a bushfire sparked by an illegal campfire near Orange Creek led to more than half of K’gari being burnt.

articles.title: Influencer cops $834 fine for lighting fire on K'gari (Fraser Island)
articles.author: Blake Antrobus
articles.summary: A social media influencer has been fined $834 for lighting a fire on K'gari (Fraser Island), a heritage-listed sand island off the coast of Queensland. She was also warned for using a drone to record video above a camping area. In October 2020, a bushfire sparked by an illegal campfire near Orange Creek, at the northeast end of the island, burned through more than half of K’gari.

articles.title: National Parks reschedules 232-hectare D'Estrees Bay burn for Wednesday
articles.author: Hui Jin
articles.summary: There were three burns planned for Kangaroo Island this spring, but none of them were successful. There was no access pass for the News and Digital Edition with an online subscription, but there was an all-access pass for News and a Digital Edition subscription.

articles.title: Influencer starts illegal fire, flies drone over campers on K'gari
articles.author: Dominique Tassell
articles.summary: An influencer has been fined $834 for starting an illegal fire on K'gari. The woman was caught after she uploaded a video of the act on the island about four weeks ago. She also received a warning for using a drone to record video above a camping area.

articles.title: UN sees world's emissions falling 10% by 2035, far short of 60% goal
articles.author: Dayang Norazhar
articles.summary: Global emissions of planet-warming greenhouse gases are expected to fall by about 10% by 2035, compared with 2019 levels. This is the first time the UN has forecast such a decline. It falls short of the 60% cut needed to keep warming close to 1.5C by the end of the century and avoid catastrophic climate change. The UNFCCC also released its NDC Synthesis Report based on countries' detailed plans known as Nationally Determined Contributions, or NDCs.

articles.title: The New Climate Reality and Systemic Financial Risk
articles.summary: In 2021, researchers at the World Bank assessed the risk to Pakistan's economy from climate change. In the worst case, the economy was projected to lose up to 10 per cent of GDP by the end of this century. Less than a year after the assessment was published, vast floods overcame the country. Pakistan's government came to account for the damage.

articles.title: COP30: a test of global climate resolve
articles.author: none@none.com
articles.summary: Representatives from nearly 200 countries are in Belem for the 2025 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP30). The world is failing to live up to its commitments made during previous climate summits. The rich bought time through rhetoric while the poorest have paid in lives, livelihoods and ecosystems. US President Donald Trump's climate scepticism has become official policy. Washington's refusal to attend the Belem summit is a clear demonstration of its hostility to the climate agenda.

articles.title: UN raises impact of Melissa: Over 3.5 million Cubans affected
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa affected more than 3.5 million Cubans. More than 90,000 homes suffered partial or total damage and about 100,000 hectares of crops were destroyed. UN presented an Action Plan for Cuba valued at $74.2 million aimed at meeting the basic needs of one million severely affected people.

articles.title: UN: The Cuban government is "overwhelmed" by the extent of the disaster left by Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The magnitude of the disaster left by Hurricane Melissa in Cuba has exceeded the government's ability to respond. More than 90,000 homes were affected or destroyed and 100,000 hectares of crops were swept away. 600 medical facilities and more than 2,000 educational centers were damaged, along with collapsed roads, bridges, power lines, and telecommunications towers. The UN has taken a central role in the humanitarian response. The organization presented an Action Plan to assist one million "severely affected" individuals, with an initial fundraising of $74.2 million. At least $11 million have already been mobilized.

articles.title: China's CO2 emissions have been flat or falling for past 18 months, analysis finds
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: World's biggest polluter is on track to hit peak emissions target early but misses goal for cutting carbon intensity.      Â   for cutting CO2 emissions, but not for CO2 intensity, as expected by the UNFCCC.

articles.title: Former United Nations chief urges countries to help Philippines recover
articles.author: Pia Lee-Brago
articles.summary: Ban Ki-moon urges the international community to help Filipinos recover from disasters that hit the country this year. Super Typhoon Uwan hit the Philippines days after Typhoon Tino ravaged parts of the Visayas. He was speaking at the Trans-Pacific Sustainability Dialogue in Makati.

articles.title: Redwoods stand strong amid wildfires—but management matters
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: California's coastal redwoods have stood for centuries, weathering a changing climate, logging and weathering the changing climate. The redwoods are threatened by climate change, logging, and other environmental issues.    .   i   in this article.

articles.title: Practical support for managing farm carbon (Dairy Australia Ltd)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Heidi Barnier, Carbon Farming Extension Expert, Dairy Australia explains practical support for managing farm carbon on 10 November 2025. Dairy farmers are aware of the growing focus on understanding and managing greenhouse gas emissions in the dairy industry and this isn't new territory for many farmers.

articles.title: The Future of Climate Progress Is Being Built in the Global South
articles.author: Time
articles.summary: The next phase of climate action is economic, and it's happening in the Global South. Ani Dasgupta writes about it in her article "The Next Phase of Climate Action is Economic".    i.dasgupta.com.

articles.title: What's climate finance, why it matters
articles.author: Gulf-Times
articles.summary: As the costs and risks of global warming escalate, the topic of climate finance has become more tense. Countries trying to shift to clean energy and prepare for extreme weather and other impacts in a warmer world will need a lot of money. What is climate finance? This describes all.

articles.title: How climate change increased the risk of earthquakes in East Africa
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Climate change is accelerating continental rifting, the geological process where landmasses slowly pull apart, according to a new study. The study was published in the journal "Geological Research Letters". It claims that climate change is speeding up the rifting process.

articles.title: Richest 0.1 Percent Guilty of the ‘Climate Plunder' Wrecking Planet Earth
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: A person from the world's richest 0.1% emits over 800kg of CO2 every day. Even the strongest person on earth could not lift this much CO2, according to the Oxfam International report. The rich are fueling the climate emergency that is intensifying weather catastrophes like Hurricane Melissa.

articles.title: Could worsening South Atlantic Anomaly spell doom for life on Earth?
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Scientists have warned of a weakening of Earth's magnetic field over the Atlantic Ocean. A growing weak spot in the magnetic field could cause serious repercussions for the Earth's dynamic magnetic field. South Atlantic Anomaly (SAA) is a region also called South Atlantic Magnetic Anomaly.

articles.title: Climate negotiations have started. Here's how far countries need to go
articles.author: National Public Radio
articles.summary: Nations have begun climate negotiations at the COP30 summit in Brazil. Studies show the world is not on track to avoid the most damaging impacts of climate change, according to the UNFCCC. The world needs to act now to prevent the worst impacts of the climate change.

articles.title: Beyond the Fire: The Science of Bushfire Risk Modelling in Australia (Verisk Analytics Inc)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Australia's bushfire landscape is dynamic and consequential. Under typical conditions, embers can travel several kilometers from their sources and jump firebreaks. They can also land on the roofs of structures considered "low risk" under some circumstances.

articles.title: How to make AMOC model experiments more realistic
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Melting ice in the Arctic is causing an increasing amount of freshwater to enter the North Atlantic. This is expected to result in a weakening of the Atlantic overturning, which will affect the weather in North America and Europe. The current situation is not a concern for the U.N.

articles.title: Recognise Wildlife As Heartbeat Of Global Climate, Conservationists Urge COP30
articles.author: Malaysian National News Agency
